prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
To estimate the expected fluxes for the CH 532 and 536 GHz lines in the proposed galaxies at z~0.1, we scale the CH lines fluxes observed in the nearby ULIRG Arp 220. The fluxes will scale down with the redshift and scale up with the far-infrared (FIR) luminosity. The flux in the CH 532 and 536 GHz lines in Arp 220 is ~1000 Jy km/s for each line. Scaling this flux to z=0.1 (F(z) = F(Arp220) * (D_L (Arp220)/D_L(z))^2), we obtain 30 Jy km/s for the CH lines at z~0.1. There are two galaxies at slightly higher redshift but they have higher FIR luminosity than Arp 220 so the final scaled flux is close to the above value.
We assume a large line width of 350 km/s, which is typical in ULIRGs. Dividing the expected line flux by this line width gives a peak flux density of 86 mJy the CH lines. Our primary science goal requires high S/N on the CH/CO line ratio to look for variation in this ratio among the proposed galaxies with high certainty. A sensitivity of 17mJy in the CH lines over a 5 km/s velocity resolution bin gives S/N = 5 on the peak flux density and S/N = 42 (5 * SQRT(70)) on the integrated flux (in Jy km/s). This is sufficiently high to determine the CH/CO ratio with high certainty and to also detect the HCN and HCO+ J = 6-5 lines simultaneously in the same science goal. In all, there are 10 science goals for observing two CH lines in 5 galaxies. The integration time for each science goal is about 30 minutes. In one instance, where the CH line is near an atmospheric transmission line, the integration time is about 11 minutes higher.
We request an array configuration that provides 0.6‚Äù resolution (in point source mode), which is ~1 kpc at z = 0.1, to verify that the CH emission is coming from the central regions of these galaxies.
We select the FDM (1875 MHz) setup for the CH lines to get 5 km/s velocity resolution and the TDM mode for the continuum windows.
For all science goals, the overheads are ~39% of the total requested time. Our sources are bright in CH and CO and do not require longer on-source integration time in Band 8. For the overhead to be less than 30% we will need to increase the on-source integration by a factor of 4, adding 4 hours to our total integration time. Such large times are not needed to accomplish our science goals.
The technical justification for this science goal is exactly the same as described in Sceince Goal "CH532 IRAS12265+0219"

The technical justification for this science goal is exactly the same as described in Sceince Goal "CH532 IRAS12265+0219"
The technical justification for this science goal is exactly the same as described in Sceince Goal "CH532 IRAS12265+0219"

To estimate the expected fluxes for CO lines in the proposed galaxies at z~0.1, we scale the CO J = 1-0 lines flux observed in the nearby ULIRG Arp 220. The flux will scale down with the redshift and scale up with the far-infrared (FIR) luminosity. The CO J = 1=0 line flux in Arp 220 is ~420 Jy km/s. Scaling this flux to z=0.1 (F(z) = F(Arp220) * (D_L (Arp220)/D_L(z))^2), we obtain 12 Jy km/s for the CO lines at z~0.1. There are two galaxies at slightly higher redshift but they have higher FIR luminosity than Arp 220 so the final scaled flux is close to the above value.
We assume a large line width of 350 km/s, which is typical in ULIRGs. Dividing the expected line flux by this line width gives a peak flux density of 34 mJy. Our primary science goal requires high S/N on the CH/CO line ratio to look for variation in this ratio among the proposed galaxies with high certainty. A sensitivity of 6.5 mJy in the CO lines over a 5 km/s velocity resolution bin gives S/N = 5 on the peak flux density and S/N = 42 (5 * SQRT(70)) on the integrated flux (in Jy km/s). This is sufficiently high to determine the CH/CO ratio with high certainty. In all, there are 5 science goals for observing the CO J = 1-0 line in 5 galaxies. The integration time for each science goal is about 30 minutes.
We request an array configuration that provides ~0.6‚Äùresolution (in point source mode), which is ~1 kpc at z = 0.1, to verify that the CO emission is coming from the central regions of these galaxies. However, if there is any extended CO emission then the array configurations (e.g., C34-6) in Band-3 can easily recover emission up to 9‚Äù for 0.6‚Äù angular resolution. This is will sufficient to account for extended CO emission if present.
We select the FDM (1875 MHz) setup for the CO lines to get 5 km/s velocity resolution and the TDM mode for the continuum windows.
For all science goals, the overheads are ~39% of the total requested time. Our sources are bright in CH and CO and do not require longer on-source integration time in Band 8. For the overhead to be less than 30% we will need to increase the on-source integration by a factor of 4, adding 4 hours to our total integration time. Such large times are not needed to accomplish our science goals.
The technical justification for this science goal is exactly the same as described in Sceince Goal "CO 1-0 IRAS12265+0219"

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The goal of this proposal is to establish the CH/CO line ratio as a discriminator between AGN and star-formation dominated galaxies by observing CH (at 560 microns) and CO (J=1-0) in five ultra-luminous infrared galaxies, with and without AGN, at z ~ 0.1. In a small sample of local galaxies observed with the Herschel Space Observatory, we found that the CH/CO abundance ratio is almost an order of magnitude higher in an AGN-dominated galaxy (NGC 1068) compared to three starburst -dominated galaxies (Arp 220, M 82 and NGC 253). This is consistent with the higher abundance of CH expected in X-ray dominated regions, fueled by the presence of the AGN. In addition, estimation of the molecular hydrogen column densities from CH and CO will enable us to test whether the CH is coming from diffuse or dense gas, and thus its reliability as a mass tracer. With the end of the Herschel mission, observations of far-infared CH lines are impossible in nearby galaxies because of atmospheric water vapor. Band-8 of ALMA can detect these lines for galaxies at z > 0.08, the lowest possible redshift for which such a study can be performed.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Mapping the Distribution of Warm Molecular Gas in Arp 220 (accpeted in Cycle-0)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)
